hints_html:
The general formula for the trapezoidal approximation \(T_n\) is given by:

\(T_n = \frac{\Delta x}{2} (f(x_0) + 2f(x_1) + \dots + 2f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_n))\)

What are \(x_0\) and \(x_n\)?
hints_latex:
The general formula for the trapezoidal approximation $T_n$ is given by:

$T_n = \frac{\Delta x}{2} (f(x_0) + 2f(x_1) + \dots + 2f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_n))$

What are $x_0$ and $x_n$?
hints_raw:
The general formula for the trapezoidal approximation <math>T_n</math> is given by: 

<math>T_n = \frac{\Delta x}{2} (f(x_0) + 2f(x_1) + \dots + 2f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_n))</math>

What are <math>x_0</math> and <math>x_n</math>?
question: 7 (a)
sols_html:
The formula for the trapezoidal approximation of the integral is as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} T_4 = \frac{\Delta x}{2} (f(x_0) + 2f(x_1) + 2f(x_2) + 2f(x_3) + f(x_4))\end{aligned}\]

The 4 of \(T_4\) means that our interval of integration has been divided into four pieces, each of length (b-a)/4=1/4. So \(\Delta x = 1/4\). We also know that \(x_0\) and \(x_4\) are the endpoints of the interval of integration. So we have

\[\begin{aligned} x_0 &= 1 \\ x_1&= 5/4 \\ x_2 &= 6/4 \\ x_3 &= 7/4 \\ x_4 &= 2 \end{aligned}\]

We simply plug this all into the formula given above to get:

\[\begin{aligned} T_4 = \frac18 \left(\frac1{1} + 2 \frac1{5/4} + 2 \frac1{6/4} + 2 \frac1{7/4} + \frac1{2}) \right)\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The formula for the trapezoidal approximation of the integral is as follows: 

: <math>T_4 = \frac{\Delta x}{2} (f(x_0) + 2f(x_1)  + 2f(x_2) + 2f(x_3) + f(x_4))</math>

The ''4'' of <math>T_4</math> means that our interval of integration has been divided into four pieces, each of length ''(b-a)/4=1/4''.  So <math>\Delta x = 1/4</math>.  We also know that <math>x_0</math> and <math>x_4</math> are the endpoints of the interval of integration.  So we have

<math>\begin{align}
x_0 &= 1 \\
x_1&= 5/4 \\
x_2 &= 6/4 \\
x_3 &= 7/4 \\
x_4 &= 2 \\
\end{align}</math>

We simply plug this all into the formula given above to get: 

:<math> 
T_4 = \frac18 \left(\frac1{1} + 2 \frac1{5/4}  + 2 \frac1{6/4} + 2 \frac1{7/4} + \frac1{2}) \right)
</math>
statement_html:
Let \(I = \int_{1}^{2} (1/x)\, dx\). Write down the trapezoidal approximation T4 for I.

You do not need to simplify your answer.
statement_raw:
Let <math> I = \int_{1}^{2} (1/x)\, dx </math>. Write down the trapezoidal approximation ''T''<sub>4</sub> for ''I''.

''You do not need to simplify your answer.''
